item.name: Pgbouncer clients count
item.description: Count rows from client table. This represents clients count.

item.name: Pgbouncer config client_idle_timeout
item.description:
Client connections idling longer than this many seconds are closed. This should be larger than the client-side connection lifetime settings, and only used for network problems. [seconds]
Default: 0.0 (disabled)

item.name: Pgbouncer config client_login_timeout
item.description:
If a client connects but does not manage to login in this amount of time, it will be disconnected. Mainly needed to avoid dead connections stalling SUSPEND and thus online restart. [seconds]
Default: 60.0

item.name: Pgbouncer config default_pool_size
item.description: default pool size. 20 is good number when transaction pooling is in use, in session pooling it needs to be the number of max clients you want to handle at any moment

item.name: Pgbouncer config idle_transaction_timeout
item.description:
If client has been in “idle in transaction” state longer, it will be disconnected. [seconds]
Default: 0.0 (disabled)

item.name: Pgbouncer config ignore_startup_parameters
item.description:
By default, PgBouncer allows only parameters it can keep track of in startup packets - client_encoding, datestyle, timezone and standard_conforming_strings.
All others parameters will raise an error. To allow others parameters, they can be specified here, so that pgbouncer knows that they are handled by admin and it can ignore them.
Default: empty

item.name: Pgbouncer config max_client_conn
item.description: Total number of clients that can connect

item.name: Pgbouncer config max_db_connections
item.description:
Do not allow more than this many connections per-database (regardless of pool - i.e. user). It should be noted that when you hit the limit, closing a client connection to one pool will not immediately allow a server connection to be established for another pool, because the server connection for the first pool is still open. Once the server connection closes (due to idle timeout), a new server connection will immediately be opened for the waiting pool.
Default: unlimited

item.name: Pgbouncer config max_packet_size
item.description:
Maximum size for PostgreSQL packets that PgBouncer allows through. One packet is either one query or one result set row. Full result set can be larger.
Default: 2147483647

item.name: Pgbouncer config max_user_connections
item.description: Do not allow more than this many connections per-user (regardless of pool - i.e. user). It should be noted that when you hit the limit, closing a client connection to one pool will not immediately allow a server connection to be established for another pool, because the server connection for the first pool is still open. Once the server connection closes (due to idle timeout), a new server connection will immediately be opened for the waiting pool.

item.name: Pgbouncer config min_pool_size
item.description:
Add more server connections to pool if below this number. Improves behavior when usual load comes suddenly back after period of total inactivity.
Default: 0 (disabled)

item.name: Pgbouncer config pool_mode
item.description: When server connection is released back to pool: session - after client disconnects transaction - after transaction finishes statement - after statement finishes

item.name: Pgbouncer config query_timeout
item.description:
Queries running longer than that are canceled. This should be used only with slightly smaller server-side statement_timeout, to apply only for network problems. [seconds]
Default: 0.0 (disabled)

item.name: Pgbouncer config query_wait_timeout
item.description:
Maximum time queries are allowed to spend waiting for execution. If the query is not assigned to a server during that time, the client is disconnected. This is used to prevent unresponsive servers from grabbing up connections. [seconds]
It also helps when server is down or database rejects connections for any reason. If this is disabled, clients will be queued infinitely.
Default: 120

item.name: Pgbouncer config reserve_pool_size
item.description:
How many additional connections to allow to a pool. 0 disables.
Default: 0 (disabled)

item.name: Pgbouncer config reserve_pool_timeout
item.description:
If a client has not been serviced in this many seconds, pgbouncer enables use of additional connections from reserve pool. 0 disables.
Default: 5.0

item.name: Pgbouncer config server_connect_timeout
item.description:
If connection and login won’t finish in this amount of time, the connection will be closed. [seconds]
Default: 15.0

item.name: Pgbouncer config server_idle_timeout
item.description:
If a server connection has been idle more than this many seconds it will be dropped. If 0 then timeout is disabled. [seconds]
Default: 600.0

item.name: Pgbouncer config server_lifetime
item.description:
The pooler will close an unused server connection that has been connected longer than this. Setting it to 0 means the connection is to be used only once, then closed. [seconds]
Default: 3600.0

item.name: Pgbouncer config server_login_retry
item.description:
If login failed, because of failure from connect() or authentication that pooler waits this much before retrying to connect. [seconds]
Default: 15.0

item.name: Pgbouncer config server_round_robin
item.description:
By default, pgbouncer reuses server connections in LIFO (last-in, first-out) manner, so that few connections get the most load. This gives best performance if you have a single server serving a database. But if there is TCP round-robin behind a database IP, then it is better if pgbouncer also uses connections in that manner, thus achieving uniform load.
Default: 0

item.name: Pgbouncer config suspend_timeout
item.description:
How many seconds to wait for buffer flush during SUSPEND or reboot (-R). Connection is dropped if flush does not succeed.
Default: 10

item.name: Pgbouncer all trapper items collection status
item.description: Running the same script with getAll param collects all items and sends them via zabbix_sender. So this is basically the cron analog. Returns Text status, so all exceptions will be show here if something goes wrong.

item.name: Pgbouncer all trapper clients items collection status
item.description: Running the same script with getClients param collects all items and sends them via zabbix_sender. So this is basically the cron analog. Returns Text status, so all exceptions will be show here if something goes wrong.

item.name: Pgbouncer all trapper config items collection status
item.description: Running the same script with getConfig param collects all items and sends them via zabbix_sender. So this is basically the cron analog. Returns Text status, so all exceptions will be show here if something goes wrong.

item.name: Pgbouncer version
item.description: Running pgbouncer version

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer databases {#DATABASE} current_connections
item_prototype.description: Current number of connections for this database.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer databases {#DATABASE} database
item_prototype.description: Actual database name pgbouncer connects to.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer databases {#DATABASE} disabled
item_prototype.description: 1 if this database is currently disabled, else 0.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer databases {#DATABASE} force_user
item_prototype.description: When user is part of the connection string, the connection between pgbouncer and PostgreSQL is forced to the given user, whatever the client user.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer databases {#DATABASE} host
item_prototype.description: Host pgbouncer connects to.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer databases {#DATABASE} max_connections
item_prototype.description: Maximum number of allowed connections for this database, as set by max_db_connections, either globally or per database.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer databases {#DATABASE} paused
item_prototype.description: 1 if this database is currently paused, else 0.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer databases {#DATABASE} pool_mode
item_prototype.description: The database’s override pool_mode, or NULL if the default will be used instead.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer databases {#DATABASE} pool_size
item_prototype.description: Maximum number of server connections.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer databases {#DATABASE} port
item_prototype.description: Port pgbouncer connects to.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer pools {#DATABASE} cl_active
item_prototype.description: Client connections that are linked to server connection and can process queries.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer pools {#DATABASE} cl_waiting
item_prototype.description: Client connections have sent queries but have not yet got a server connection.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer pools {#DATABASE} maxwait
item_prototype.description: How long the first (oldest) client in queue has waited, in seconds. If this starts increasing, then the current pool of servers does not handle requests quick enough. Reason may be either overloaded server or just too small of a pool_size setting.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer pools {#DATABASE} maxwait_us
item_prototype.description: Microsecond part of the maximum waiting time.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer pools {#DATABASE} sv_active
item_prototype.description: Server connections that linked to client.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer pools {#DATABASE} sv_idle
item_prototype.description: Server connections that unused and immediately usable for client queries.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer pools {#DATABASE} sv_login
item_prototype.description: Server connections currently in logging in process.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer pools {#DATABASE} sv_tested
item_prototype.description: Server connections that are currently running either server_reset_query or server_check_query.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer pools {#DATABASE} sv_used
item_prototype.description: Server connections that have been idle more than server_check_delay, so they needs server_check_query to run on it before it can be used.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} avg_query_count
item_prototype.description: Average queries per second in last stat period.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} avg_query_time
item_prototype.description: Average query duration in microseconds.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} avg_recv
item_prototype.description: Average received (from clients) bytes per second.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} avg_sent
item_prototype.description: Average sent (to clients) bytes per second.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} avg_wait_time
item_prototype.description: Time spent by clients waiting for a server in microseconds (average per second).

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} avg_xact_count
item_prototype.description: Average transactions per second in last stat period.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} avg_xact_time
item_prototype.description: Average transaction duration in microseconds.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} db_queues
item_prototype.description: Total number of SQL queries proxied (or "pooled" as they say) by pgbouncer. Also known in modern pgbouncer versions as total_query_count. This metric allow easily spot a sudden change in usual Postgres / PgBouncer load profile.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} db_transactions
item_prototype.description: Total number of SQL transactions proxied (or as the doc says "pooled") by pgbouncer into a specific database.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} total_query_count
item_prototype.description: Total number of SQL queries pooled by pgbouncer.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} total_query_time
item_prototype.description: Total number of microseconds spent by pgbouncer when actively connected to PostgreSQL, executing queries.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} total_received
item_prototype.description: Total volume in bytes of network traffic received by pgbouncer.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} total_sent
item_prototype.description: Total volume in bytes of network traffic sent by pgbouncer.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} total_wait_time
item_prototype.description: Time spent by clients waiting for a server in microseconds.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} total_xact_count
item_prototype.description: Total number of SQL transactions pooled by pgbouncer.

item_prototype.name: Pgbouncer stats {#DATABASE} total_xact_time
item_prototype.description: Total number of microseconds spent by pgbouncer when connected to PostgreSQL in a transaction, either idle in transaction or executing queries.

trigger_prototype.name: Pgbouncer {#DATABASE} pool out of free connections
trigger_prototype.description: Client Pool exhausted for this database. This indicates performance issues on client side. We need to wait for free connection.

graph_prototype.name: Pgbouncer {#DATABASE} client queues rate per 20 seconds TO Pgbouncer
Pgbouncer {#DATABASE} client transactions rate per 20 seconds TO Pgbouncer

trigger.name: Pgbouncer available client connections is less than 10
trigger.description: Difference between max_client_connection parameter and current connected clients. some clients may receive tcp reset if we try to open connection above limit.

trigger.name: Pgbouncer data gathering is stopped
trigger.description: Something wrong with gathering script (zabbix-bgbouncer). Item must contain error.
